comments:
After having trouble getting selfhosting to work (my launch just wouldn't start), I checked my log and 
found a bunch of exceptions.

First, are a ton of exceptions like this one:

!SESSION 2004-11-11 12:25:02.663 -----------------------------------------------
eclipse.buildId=I200411111200
java.version=1.4.2_01
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=linux, ARCH=x86, WS=gtk, NL=en_US
Command-line arguments: -activities

!ENTRY org.eclipse.update.configurator 2004-11-11 12:25:02.665
!MESSAGE sync failed

!ENTRY org.eclipse.pde.core 1 1 2004-11-11 12:25:18.402
!MESSAGE Problems encountered while PDE was scanning the Target Platform
!SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.pde.junit.runtime 1 1 2004-11-11 12:25:18.403
!MESSAGE This plug-in (located at "/home/jburns/host/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.junit.runtime_3.
1.0") was ignored because another version of the same plug-in (located at "/home/jburns/host/eclipse/
plugins/org.eclipse.pde.junit.runtime_3.1.0") was picked

Then there are a bunch of these (when I was trying to launch):

!ENTRY org.eclipse.osgi 2004-11-11 14:56:02.244
!MESSAGE While loading class "org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.launcher.LaunchListener", thread "Worker-
46" timed out waiting (5000ms) for thread "Worker-40" to finish starting bundle "org.eclipse.pde.ui". To 
avoid deadlock, thread "Worker-46" is proceeding but "org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.launcher.
LaunchListener" may not be fully initialized.
!STACK 0
java.lang.Exception: Generated exception.
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseClassLoader.findLocalClass(EclipseClassLoader.java:102)
	at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleLoader.findLocalClass(BundleLoader.java:371)
	at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleLoader.findClass(BundleLoader.java:402)
	at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.adaptor.core.AbstractClassLoader.loadClass(AbstractClassLoader.java:
93)
	at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoader.java:235)
	at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClassInternal(ClassLoader.java:302)
	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.PDEPlugin.getLaunchListener(PDEPlugin.java:240)
	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.launcher.WorkbenchLaunchConfigurationDelegate.
launch(WorkbenchLaunchConfigurationDelegate.java:73)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchConfiguration.launch(LaunchConfiguration.java:569)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.DebugUIPlugin.buildAndLaunch(DebugUIPlugin.java:732)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.DebugUIPlugin$6.run(DebugUIPlugin.java:904)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:66)

the sync failed is coming from Update.  Dorian, this message usually 
accompanies the parser exception from yesterday.. What does it mean?

Jared, did you find these log entries in the log of your host or runtime 
instance?

If it's your host, then it's not a PDE issue, but rather a runtime issue as 
the problem was with loading classes from PDE.

Try launching your host with -clean.  If it does not work, we'll reassign the 
defect to Platform/Runtime.
I've already restarted because I needed to get some work done. Restarting fixed the problem.

The message is also reported in bug 78364 (on XP not linux)
I could not reproduce the problem, see comments there.

Not being able to self host is a different issue, and at this point I can't 
tell whether it is PDE or Update.

It is a classloading problem that is outside the PDE realm.  Moving to 
Platform/Runtime to resolve as appropriate.  The log entry from pde.core is 
unrelated.

The "Generated exception" from the class loader is just a warning. It's telling
you that a thread is trying to load a class in org.eclipse.pde.ui while another
thread is running Plugin.start/startup for that plugin.  This can cause problems
because the second thread might be accessing a partially initialized plugin.  It
doesn't actually throw the exception or cause class loads to fail - it just
dumps the exception to the log and proceeds.

Moving to PDE to see if this might be problematic - will the second thread try
to access state that is only initialized during plugin startup?  If this isn't a
problem for you, you can close this.

I suspect that such scenario would be problematic for PDE.  Will keep bug open 
for further investigation.

The disconcerting portion of this bug report which is the dup message in the 
log would not occur after changes made in the startup sequence for M7.
